Article.Abstract: The early secreted antigenic target 6-kDa protein (ESAT-6) and culture filtrate protein 10 (CFP-10) are promising antigens for reliable immunodiagnosis of tuberculosis. Both antigens are encoded by RD1, a genomic region present in all strains of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and M. bovis but lacking in all M. bovis bacillus Calmette-Gu√©rin vaccine strains. Production and purification of recombinant antigens are laborious and costly, precluding rapid and large-scale testing. Aiming to develop alternative diagnostic reagents, we have investigated whether recombinant ESAT-6 (rESAT-6) and recombinant CFP-10 (rCFP-10) can be replaced with corresponding mixtures of overlapping peptides spanning the complete amino acid sequence of each antigen. Proliferation of M. tuberculosis-specific human T-cell lines in response to rESAT-6 and rCFP-10 and that in response to the corresponding peptide mixtures were almost completely correlated (r = 0.96, P < 0.0001 for ESAT-6; r = 0.98, P < 0.0001 for CFP-10). More importantly, the same was found when gamma interferon production by peripheral blood mononuclear cells in response to these stimuli was analyzed (r = 0.89, P < 0.0001 for ESAT-6; r = 0.89, P < 0.0001 for CFP-10). Whole protein antigens and the peptide mixtures resulted in identical sensitivity and specificity for detection of infection with M. tuberculosis. The peptides in each mixture contributing to the overall response varied between individuals with different HLA-DR types. Interestingly, responses to CFP-10 were significantly higher in the presence of HLA-DR15, which is the major subtype of DR2. These results show that mixtures of synthetic overlapping peptides have potency equivalent to that of whole ESAT-6 and CFP-10 for sensitive and specific detection of infection with M. tuberculosis, and peptides have the advantage of faster production at lower cost.
Article.ArticleTitle: Antigenic equivalence of human T-cell responses to Mycobacterium tuberculosis-specific RD1-encoded protein antigens ESAT-6 and culture filtrate protein 10 and to mixtures of synthetic peptides.
Article.Affiliations: Department of Infectious Diseases, Leiden University Medical Center, Leiden, The Netherlands. smarend@lumc.nl.
Article.ArticleChemicalList: Antigens, Bacterial;Bacterial Proteins;CFP-10 protein, Mycobacterium tuberculosis;ESAT-6 protein, Mycobacterium tuberculosis;HLA-DR Antigens;Peptides;Recombinant Proteins;Interferon-gamma
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Antigens, Bacterial(genetics; immunology); Bacterial Proteins(genetics; immunology); HLA-DR Antigens(classification); Histocompatibility Testing; Humans; Immunologic Tests; Interferon-gamma(metabolism); Lymphocyte Activation; Mycobacterium tuberculosis(immunology); Peptides(chemical synthesis; immunology); Recombinant Proteins(immunology); T-Lymphocytes(immunology); Tuberculosis, Pulmonary(diagnosis)

AssayInformation.AssayComments: All 6 ESAT-6-positive PBMCs from tuberculosis patients responded to this epitope. The mixture of 9 overlapping peptides spanning the entire ESAT-6 gave higher responses than any of the individual peptides alone. The epitope's specificity and sensibility correlated well with the recombinant ESAT-6, suggesting its use as a diagnostic reagent for tuberculosis.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: T cell lines were established from PBMC by in vitro stimulation with source species sonicate for 6 days and assessed for source species specificity. Either autologous or HLA-matched PBMCs were used as stimulating cells.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: All 6 source protein-positive individual cell lines from tuberculosis patients were positive for this epitope. 2 cell lines negative for the source protein were also negative for this epitope. The mixture of 9 overlapping peptides spanning the entire source protein gave higher responses than any of the individual peptides alone. The epitope's specificity and sensibility correlated well with the recombinant source protein, suggesting its use as a diagnostic reagent for tuberculosis.

4 out of 6 source protein-positive PBMCs from tuberculosis patients responded to this epitope. The mixture of 9 overlapping peptides spanning the entire source protein gave higher responses than any of the individual peptides alone. The epitope's specificity and sensibility correlated well with the recombinant source protein, suggesting its use as a diagnostic reagent for tuberculosis. .

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: T cell lines were established from PBMC by in vitro stimulation with MTB sonicate for 6 days.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: 3 out of 6 ESAT-6-positive individual cell lines from tuberculosis patients were positive for this epitope. 2 cell lines negative for the ESAT-6 were also negative for this epitope. The mixture of 9 overlapping peptides spanning the entire ESAT-6 gave higher responses than any of the individual peptides alone. The epitope's specificity and sensibility correlated well with the recombinant ESAT-6, suggesting its use as a diagnostic reagent for tuberculosis.

3 out of 7 CFP10-positive PBMCs from tuberculosis patients responded to this epitope. The mixture of 9 overlapping peptides spanning the entire CFP10 gave higher responses than any of the individual peptides alone. The epitope's specificity and sensibility correlated well with the recombinant CFP10, suggesting its use as a diagnostic reagent for tuberculosis.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: T cell lines were established from PBMC by in vitro stimulation with MTB sonicate for 6 days.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: All 6 of the CFP10-positive cell lines from tuberculosis patients did not respond to this epitope. 2 cell lines negative for the CFP10 were also negative for this epitope. The mixture of 9 overlapping peptides spanning the entire CFP10 gave higher responses than any of the individual peptides alone. The epitope's specificity and sensibility correlated well with the recombinant CFP10, suggesting its use as a diagnostic reagent for tuberculosis.

4 out of 7 CFP10-positive PBMCs from tuberculosis patients responded to this epitope.
